Does the company have a privacy, diversity and sustainability officer in the C-Suite?
explanation: Embedding the principles of privacy, diversity and sustainability at a high-level at the com-pany is the best way to ensure that these are actually upheld. This metric is not relevant for startups or small companies.

text: Does the company ensure GDPR compliance?
Is the company a B-Corp?
explanation: B-Corps is a certification given to companies that uphold the principles of social and ecological sustainability.

text: Does the company take grid-load and energy mix into account?
Does the company have a green strategy?
What programming language is mainly be used?
explanation: Some programming languages take longer, more memory and more energy to solve specific problems than others.

text: Will the code be compiled or interpreted?
explanation: Interpreted programming languages are easier to write, but require more energy to run than using a compiled programming languages.

text: If a desktop or mobile app, is it native or web-based?
explanation: Web-based applications are cross-platform and allow for the easy deployment across multiple operating systems, while native applications are typically highly dependent on OS. However a native application requires much less energy since it does not depend on a personal browser instance to run. Choosing a web-based framework could make sense for a private, low-user application which is used by a heterogeneous group of users.

text: If a networked app, are requests cached on the receiver?
explanation: Sending information over the web requires a lot of energy, so if it all possible non-single use data should be cached on disk.

text: If a networked app, does it use a private, public or mixed cloud?
explanation: A private cloud is more secure and private, but is less sustainable than a public cloud. This choice is highly dependent on the organizational requirements.

text: Is it proprietary, copyleft or permissive?
explanation: Free software allows for the modification of the source code, use by the broader community and can serve a hedge for the company going bankrupt. Copyleft requires changes to be shared under the same license, while permissive does not. Typically having it be free software is a net-positive, but the choice on the type may depend per project.

text: If a web-based app, does it lazy-load assets?
explanation: Lazy loading allows a page to render and request and push content at a later time. It contributes to the efficiency of operations and decreases energy consumption at runtime.

text: Are non-essential tasks done in the background?
explanation: Performing tasks in the background allows for better utilization of the computer resources since it makes use of all cores, it also gives a better use experience.

text: If not a mobile app, is it virtualized?
explanation: Virtualization for better isolation between processes increasing security. It also allows for a tighter management of the resources used by the application, allowing for the closer packing of software packages and higher utilization of resources.

text: If UI-based, is there a dark-mode?
explanation: Dark mode consumes less energy than a light mode, especially on OLED devices where the pixels are actually physically turned off.

text: Does the company have a style guide?
explanation: By following a style guide a project has a consistent coding style throughout the project which is a sign for better code health.

text: Is static analysis applied on the code?
explanation: Static analysis tools scan the project for any faults, security issues or style issues. This makes sure that code health is maintained and that some bugs do not appear in the final product.

text: Which, if any, certifications (ex. MISRA) does the project have?
explanation: Some companies and alliances provide certifications that indicate that the project has a certain quality standard. A classical example of this is MISRA for embedded devices used in automotive, aerospace and critical infrastructure.

text: Is the software subject to regular security audits?
explanation: All software has bugs, by frequently auditing the software for vulnerabilities problems may be found much earlier and catastrophic failure can be avoided. This relevant for large or mission critical programs.
